newsitem.title: HUNGARY: SAAB, ELECTROLUX SPEARHEAD HUNGARY FIGHTER DEAL BID.
newsitem.headline: SAAB, ELECTROLUX SPEARHEAD HUNGARY FIGHTER DEAL BID.

text.p: Sweden's Saab and Electrolux , both owned by the Wallenberg sphere, announced plans on Friday to invest several hundred million dollars in Hungary and to create up to 20,000 jobs.
The investment is part of offset deals related to Saab's bid to sell Gripen JAS 39 fighter aircraft to Hungary through a consortium with British Aerospace .

"Under our plan 'Source Hungary' we will build a new Hungarian infrastructure for subcontracting by small amd medium sized companies," Saab president and CEO Bengt Halse told Reuters after opening Gripen's new Budapest office.
"Certainly the investment involves several hundred million dollars and in terms of jobs we are talking about something like 5,000 direct jobs and maybe 20,000 indirect jobs."
The inauguration of the Gripen office coincided with the opening on Friday of a new $15 million Electrolux chest freezer plant at Jaszbereny, 80 kilomteres (50 miles) south of the capital.
Saab is competing with a number of aircraft makers to replace Hungary's fleet of Soviet MiG-21s and MiG-23s which will be obsolete by the end of the century.
Most analysts believe the two most likely candidates are Lockheed's F16, either new or used, and the Gripen.

Also in the race are McDonnell Douglas/Northrop's F-18 and Dassault's Mirage 2000-5 while Russia's state arms agency Rosvooruzhenie was also reported last month to be considering offering Su-27s, Su-30s and Su-39s.
The fighter procurement tender had been due for publication last summer but Hungary postponed the decision until after a decision by NATO on expansion, expected in July 1997.
Halse stressed that the "Source Hungary" programme was linked to Gripen's prospects of winning the fighter tender.
"It's a lot of money, that's why it has to be linked to making a business like Gripen in Hungary," he said,
"If we have a business which will take us into a long-term relationship with the country's government, then this will be one of the deal-makers in making these long-term investments."
Helse added the Saab/BAE consortium was also preparing a financial package to put to the Hungarian government which would be "extremely attractive" but declined to give details.

The Wallenberg group was the first to sign an industrial offset deal with the Hungarian government in September 1995 to purchase Hungarian-made goods as part of a possible deal to buy JAS 39 fighters.
Hungary signed similar deals with General Electric Trading and with Lockheed Martin Corp of the United States earlier this year.

Electrolux Hungary's president Tibor Kertesz, told Hungary Electrolux's part of the "Source Hungary" programme was worth nine billion forints ($51 million) over the next two to three years and aimed to increase the Hungarian-made content of its Hungarian plants from 35 percent to over 50 percent.
